|Title=Knowing how to evoke intracranial hypertension (ICHT) and epilepsy in a patient with an intracerebral tumour.
|Description=Know the two main emergencies (ICHT, epilepsy) revealing or complicating the evolution of a brain tumour.
|Rubric=Identification of the emergency
|Contributors=Dr Thiébaud PICART (Hospices Civils de Lyon),Dr Pierre ANTHÉRIEU (Toulouse University Hospital),Pr François VASSAL (Saint-Etienne University Hospital)
|Order=8}}

'''HTIC:'''

- In cases of large tumours, major oedema, obstructive hydrocephalus and/or intra-tumour bleeding

- Screen for possible ophthalmological complications of HTIC (damage to the II, VI)

- Monitor for the onset of drowsiness, loss of alertness (Glasgow score +++), which may lead to non-traumatic coma in adults and children and death due to cerebral involvement.

'''[[Childhood and adult epilepsy|Epilepsy]] with''' '''état de mal:''''

- Prolonged seizure or repeated seizures without inter-ictal return to consciousness

- Risk of cardio-tension collapse, hypoxia, rhabdomyolysis, multi-visceral failure, cerebral ischaemia, death

question.title: What are the two main emergencies that can reveal or complicate the evolution of a brain tumour?

option_a.title: Intracranial hypertension and stroke
option_a.description: A possible complication of brain tumour

option_b.title: Epilepsy and hydrocephalus
option_b.description: Two main emergencies that can reveal or complicate the evolution of a brain tumour

option_c.title: Tumour growth and metastasis
option_c.description: A possible consequence of untreated brain tumour

option_d.title: Infection and meningitis
option_d.description: A possible complication of brain tumour
